0.user_question: In one year, the number of students on campus doubles at the end of every month. If there are 885342 students on campus at the beginning of the year, how many additional students would have joined by the end of May, above and beyond the number of students already on campus at the beginning of the year?

1.subquestion: Find out what will be the population count midway between January (beginning) and June; i.e., find P(0.5).

subanswer.text: Since student population doubles every month from an initial value 'P', then its growth follows exponential function \( f(x) = Pe^{rt} \), where r= ln(2)/month because doubling rate here corresponds to Euler’s constant e^ln x -> X when base x equals natural logarithm LN. Henceforth calculate using formula likewise below:-   \(\displaystyle\text{January population } P_{j}=Pe^{\frac{\mathrm{LN}(2)}{1}}=885\,342\). Similarly compute subsequent months until December:\(\displaystyle\text{December Population}\)= \(PE^{\frac{\mathrm{LN}(2)^{12}}{1}}\)=\(P*(e^{\mathrm{LN}{2}})^{\mathrm{LN}{(2)} ^ {12}/1}=\sqrt[1]{E^{12*\mathrm{LN}{2}}}\) (\(=\sqrt[\leftroot{-2}\uproot{2}\scriptstyle 12]{\mathrm{C}^{12*2}})\)). Note also during computation you may simplify numerically if needed.\([i]\))    Subsequently computing intermediate values up till fifth term yields following results correspondingly;\([ii]\)     January :        885342 ([i])        February:         1770684 (=885342*2=[i]))       March :           3541368               (=1770684*2=[i]))      April:            7082736                (=3541368*2,[i]))           May:             14165472                    (=7082736*2,[i])) To satisfy condition mentioned within problem statement regarding finding required quantity ‘X,’ let us take summation over all terms starting from second (February): thus ,we get :- [\((+)-rhs]] & hence ; \[X =\sum ^{k}_{l=2}T_l \] \[\color{red} [where k := n-d ]\] Here no need to specify d since requirement concerns counting five intervals exclusively.[iii] Using calculated figures,\(X=(1770684)+(3541368)+(7082736)+(14165472)\\ =26

0.user_question: In one year, the number of students on campus doubles at the end of every month. If there are 885342 students on campus at the beginning of the year, how many additional students would have joined by the end of May, above and beyond the number of students already on campus at the beginning of the year?

1.subquestion: Find out what will be the population count midway between January (beginning) and June; i.e., find P(0.5).

subanswer.text:
Let's first establish the equation based on exponential growth per month starting with `P_initial` being the initial student population. Given it doubled once already until February we would write this as:  
\[ P(t) = P_{initial} \times 2^t \]  
Where \( t \) represents time elapsed since January measured in months. Since you want half way through six months, or three months into our timeline (\( t = 3/2 \)), let’s plug this value back into the formula above using appropriate values assuming any arbitrary starting point such as say \( P_{initial}=1\) which simplifies calculation without loss of generality due to proportional change over all periods:
\[ P(0.5)=1 \times 2^{3/2} \]   
Now computing power of fractional exponents remembering \(a^{m/n}=\sqrt{a^m}\):    
\[=2^{\frac{3}{2}}=\sqrt{2^3}=\sqrt{8}\approx 2.83\]  
This means if initially there was just ‘one person,’ after going through similar patterns described previously up till April 'cause May and June haven'
